newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ details plans to simplify tax rules from 1998.
newsitem.headline: NZ details plans to simplify tax rules from 1998.

text.p: The New Zealand Government would introduce legislation this month simplifying provisional tax rules from the 1998-99 income year, Finance and Revenue Minister Bill Birch said on Friday.
Birch said the changes aimed to reduce compliance costs. The complexity of provisional tax rules had long been a source of concern to provisional taxpayers and tax practitioners.

"The objective of the provisional tax rules is to ensure that businesses pay tax on income in the year when it is earned, but the current rules are a maze of thresholds, penalties and interest provisions," he said in a statement.
He said he had no doubt business taxpayers and tax practitioners would welcome the proposed changes, especially the removal of the unpopular underestimation penalty.
Birch said the main changes would be -
* Removal of the underestimation penalty. At present those who significantly underestimate their taxable income pay a penalty of 10 percent of the underestimated amount.
* The definition of "provisional taxpayer" would be extended to ensure those who had overpaid provisional tax received interest.
* The rules covering changes of balance date would be set out in legislation to provide improved certainty for taxpayers.
* Payment dates later in January would recognise that many people were on holiday in early January.
